citation.article-title: Deinococcus aetherius sp. nov., isolated from the stratosphere
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Deinococcus aetherius sp. nov.
Deinococcus aetherius (a.e.the′ri.us. L. masc. adj. aetherius belonging to the upper air, referring to the isolation site of the type strain).
Colonies are circular, convex, pink-red pigmented (non-fluorescent) and shiny with smooth edges.
Cells are spherical, 1.0–1.5 μm in diameter, non-spore-forming and non-motile.
The optimal growth temperature range on mTGE-GP is 25–30 °C.
Cells typically grow slowly in clusters and are highly resistant to desiccation, γ-ray (D10 >8 kGy) and UV radiation (D10 1000 J m−2).
Major peptidoglycan amino acids are d-glutamic acid, glycine, d-alanine, l-alanine and ornithine.
Major fatty acids are C16 : 1ω7c, C16 : 0, C17 : 0 and iso-C17 : 0.
Polar lipid profile is complex, consisting of various unknown phosphoglycolipids (including a predominant phosphoglycolipid), glycolipids, and phospholipids.
Can hydrolyse aesculin, reduce nitrate to nitrite, and possesses catalase, oxidase, arginine arylamidase, pyrrolidone arylamidase and β-galactosidase activities.
Can use glycerol and asparagine as carbon sources.
DNA G+C content of the type strain is 69.8 mol%.
The type strain, ST0316T (=JCM 11751T =DSM 21230T), was isolated from an air sample collected in the stratosphere, Japan.
